text: Go to the Eurostat. Select EU trade 1988-2022 by CPA 2008, pick partner Russia, flow Export, product Beer and indicator Quantity_in_100kg.

title: EU export and import to Russia and its neighbours
text:
Russia war on Ukraine had an impact to EU and Russia trade. The goal of this document is to analyze these changes.
The data was taken from Eurostat. The code and data can be found in the Github repository.

title: EU export and import to Russia and its neighbours
text:
Russia war on Ukraine had an impact to EU and Russia trade. The goal of this document is to analyze these changes.
The analysis of overall trade impact is presented followed by the analysis of sanctioned export. The data used comes from Eurostat. See the @appendix for technical details.


Trade with Russia dropped significantly after Russia invasion on February 24th. However the export to Russia neighbours has increased meaning that companies are evading sanctions on exports to Russia by exporting to its neighbours instead.

Data
The data used comes from Eurostat dataset on internation trade in goods.
All the code and data resides in the Github repository:

title: EU export and import to Russia and its neighbours
text:
Sanction anomalies
Export to Russia sanction evasion should be visible by increased export to other countries. Define anomaly as the export which is more than 10 million euro in value and which doubled after a war.

Reporter and partner pairs
Individual exporter and importer pairs are analyzed. The growth with empty values means that the export in year 2021 from March to October was zero.
Using the anomaly definition 97 export categories stand out. It is interesting that there are 23 categories of sanctioned exports to Russia which experienced triple digit growth.
The biggest of anomalous exports in term of value are motor cars. Lithuania topping the list with 141 millions euro export to Belarus which doubled compared to previous year. Germany exports of motor cars to Belarus and Russia grew ~7 times for cars with cylinder capacity between 1.5 and 2 litres. Germany exports of motor cars with cylinder capacity larger than 2 litres grew 25 times. This amounted to 361 milion euro of exports after the war.
Poland exported 139 millions of euro worth turbojets to Kazakhstan, and these exports grew 2 times. Czechia exported 162 millions euro of smartphones to Kazakhstan and Armenia , which is notable as in 2021 there were no such exports at the same period.
Latvia exported 34 millions euro worth of sparling wine to Russia and these exports grew 4 times.
Greece exported 58 millions euro worth of jet fuel to Georgia. These exports grew by ~3400 times compared to similar period in 2021.
